content.introduction: The development of large language models (LLMs) has undergone significant transformations since the 1990s. Early models, such as IBM's statistical models and smoothed n-gram models, laid the groundwork for corpus-based language modeling. The introduction of neural networks and deep learning architectures in the 2000s marked a significant shift in language modeling, leading to the development of more advanced models.
content.development: The introduction of transformer-based models in 2017 revolutionized the field of natural language processing. The transformer architecture, introduced by Google researchers in 2017, improved upon sequence-to-sequence technology and was based on the attention mechanism. BERT, an encoder-only model, was introduced in 2018 and became widely used. Decoder-only models, such as GPT-2 and GPT-3, also gained attention for their capabilities. The release of ChatGPT in 2022 led to widespread media coverage and public attention. Since then, many LLMs have been developed, including multimodal models that can process and generate other types of data, such as images and audio. Open-source models, such as BLOOM and LLaMA, have gained popularity, and some models, like DeepSeek R1, have achieved comparable performance to OpenAI's models at a lower cost.
content.conclusion: The development of LLMs has rapidly advanced in recent years, with transformer-based models dominating the field. The rise of open-source models and multimodal LLMs has expanded the possibilities for language modeling, with many applications across various fields.
